tossups.question: In one of the Gathas, one of these animals laments its sorrowful existence before Ahura Mazda. They’re not cats, but black examples of these animals that were thought to have been conceived by lightning or moonlight were mummified and buried in Saqqara. Up to one hundred of these animals were sprinkled with barley-meal at the start of a hecatomb (“HECK-uh-toom”). In Ancient Egypt, these animals were venerated near (*) Memphis as the manifestation of Ptah. In surviving reliefs depicting the mystery religion of Mithraism, swords are plunged into the necks of these animals in a ritual called the tauroctony (“tor-OK-tuh-nee”). Minoan frescoes often depict athletes leaping over, for 10 points, what animals that were raised for livestock?
tossups.answer: cows [or bulls; or cattle; or oxen; or bovines] <AG, Religion>

tossups.question: In a form of “distillation” named for this phenomenon, the input is many copies of an arbitrary system that “weakly” displays this phenomenon, and LOCC methods are used to output a system that “maximally” displays this phenomenon. A bipartite system displays this phenomenon if and only if it cannot be decomposed into the tensor product of two kets. The pilot wave theory of de Broglie (“duh BROY”) and Bohm and other (*) hidden variable theories were developed to explain this phenomenon, whose incompatibility with local realism is the subject of the EPR paradox. Since this phenomenon apparently violates causality, Einstein derided it with the phrase “spooky action at a distance.” For 10 points, name this phenomenon where the quantum states of two physically separated particles depend on each other.
tossups.answer: quantum entanglement [accept word forms like entangled] <BB, Physics>

tossups.question: The accusation that Aulus Licinius Archias had not been subjected to this action led to his student Cicero defending him in the oration Pro Archia Poeta. The younger Marcus Livius Drusus was assassinated for supporting a bill that would have performed this action. This action was performed in places such as Etruria by a 90 BC Lex Julia as a reward to allied towns. Gaius Gracchus proposed a bill that would have performed this action, which was rejected by plebeians who feared competition for the grain dole, and was a major cause behind the (*) Social War. This action was carried out through the Constitutio Antoniniana, which mostly applied to those living outside of Italy. For 10 points, name this action most notably carried out by Caracalla in 212 AD, which granted full rights to residents of all provinces within his empire.
tossups.answer: expanding Roman citizenship [accept descriptive answers that mention becoming a citizen of Rome such as granting citizenship or giving citizenship; prompt on just citizenship by asking “what action is occurring?”; prompt on becoming Roman by asking “in what way?”] <TR, Other History>

tossups.question: Much of this composer’s earlier work was revived thanks to editions and advocacy by H. C. Robbins Landon. The introduction to this composer’s last symphony opens with the orchestra in unison using a double-dotted rhythm to play the ascending fifth “D, D, D A.” The second movement of one of his symphonies begins with the slow eighth notes “C C, E E, G G, E.” Another symphony by this composer is unusually in F-sharp minor, ends with the musicians one by one (*) leaving the stage, and was written while in residence for Prince Esterházy. For a 1791 trip, this composer wrote a symphony whose slow movement is interrupted by a sudden G-major chord. For 10 points, name this Classical composer whose 104 symphonies have nicknames like “Farewell,” “London,” and “Surprise.”
tossups.answer: (Franz) Joseph Haydn <AWD, Music>

tossups.question: A character with this first name fondles some “satin shoes” with soles yellowed with wax from a dance floor at a ball whose memory “became an occupation.” Love for a character with this first name is the subject of Mario Vargas Llosa’s The Perpetual Orgy. A lifelong hypochondriac is cared for at (*) Hartfield by his daughter, who has this name. An inept attempt to persuade Harriet Smith to turn down Mr. Martin leads George Knightley to chide a character with this name. Another character with this name has sex in a moving carriage as part of an affair with Léon. For 10 points, give this name shared by the title characters of a novel by Jane Austen and Flaubert’s Madame Bovary.
tossups.answer: Emma [accept Emma Woodhouse or Emma Bovary] <JG, Long Fiction>

tossups.question: One of these characters was asked by his father to kill his mother as punishment for her becoming distracted by the sight of spirits frolicking in a river. Another of these characters steps on a demon king’s head as the last of his requested “three paces of land.” One of these characters jumps out of a broken pillar on a threshold at twilight in order to kill an otherwise-indestructible demon, and takes the form of a half-man half-lion. The (*) last of these characters will appear with a flaming sword on a white horse to end the Kali Yuga. The dwarf Vamana, Narasimha, the axe-wielding Parashurama, and Kalki are all examples of these characters, as are Buddha, Rama, and Krishna. For 10 points, give the term for these incarnations of a Hindu preserver god.
tossups.answer: avatars of Vishnu [or Dashavatara; accept synonyms for “avatar” like incarnation before “incarnations”; prompt on partial answers] <RC, Mythology>

tossups.question: A character created by this playwright gives a monologue in which she asks the Virgin Mary “Where were you when me darlin’ son was riddled by bullets?” This author’s six-volume autobiography was published under the title Mirror in My House. One of this playwright’s characters looks up at the sky and asks himself “What is the moon? What is the stars?” That character declares the world to be “in a terrible state o’ (*) chassis” at the end of the play. A one-armed man named Johnny feels guilty for his betrayal of Robbie Tancred, which leads to Robbie’s death, in a play by this man in which Joxer Daly hangs out at the pub with Captain Jack Boyle. For 10 points, name this Irish author of Juno and the Paycock.
tossups.answer: Sean O’Casey [or John Casey] <WN, Drama>

tossups.question: Joshua Epstein and Robert Axtell’s Sugarscape is a social simulation model based on people referred to by this specific term. The structuration theory of Anthony Giddens is a method of analysis based both on the notion of “structure” and on a notion with this name. In linguistics, a thematic relation of this name is exemplified by “Mary” in the sentence “Mary petted the cat,” in which “the cat” is the (*) patient. A problem in economic theory closely related to moral hazard problems is named after “principals” and these people. They’re not representatives, but someone who has a contractual agreement with an insurance policy owner is called one of these people “of record.” For 10 points, identify this specific term, which in law refers to someone authorized to act on another’s behalf, and which in economics refers to any actor or decision-maker.
tossups.answer: agents [or agency; do not accept or prompt on “proxy”] <WN, Social Science>

tossups.question: Neil Immermann defined this set as the group of entities expressed in first-order logic with a least fixed-point operator over ordered structures. This set is the subject of a thesis by Jack Edmonds and Alan Cobham, which concerns the “feasibility” of its members. Adding the power of randomness to the mathematical model used to define this set can be used to define the “bounded-error (*) probabilistic” counterpart to this set. This set consists of the decision problems that are solvable in a tractable amount of time, such as linear programming problems and the greatest common divisor problem. It is an open question whether it is equal to its non-deterministic counterpart. For 10 points, name this class from computational complexity that may be equal to NP.
tossups.answer: P [or polynomial time] <IJ, Other Science - Computer Science>

tossups.question: This man’s rise to power began in 1987, when he was sent by his best friend to address regional tensions, but ended up stoking them by telling a crowd being forced back by police batons that “no one will dare beat you again.” This man spurred the “anti-bureaucratic revolution,” which culminated when he gave a 1989 speech at the Gazimestan Monument commemorating the 600th anniversary of a battle at which national hero Miloš (*) Obilić supposedly assassinated an Ottoman sultan. Under this former protégé of Ivan Stambolić, the general Ratko Mladić ordered the execution of over 8,000 Bosniaks at Srebrenica in 1995. For 10 points, what president of Serbia died in prison in The Hague while facing war crimes charges for ethnic cleansing committed in the 1990s?
tossups.answer: Slobodan Milošević <AH, European History>

tossups.question: Erwin Panofsky noted how an architectural patron from this country exalted God as the “Father of Lights” in the Neoplatonist poems included in his Latin autobiography titled On What Was Done in His Administration. An architectural style that started around 1240 in this country has a name meaning “radiating” in reference to the spokes of (*) rose windows. A cathedral in this country which is said to house the tunic that the Virgin Mary wore during Christ’s birth features a well-preserved labyrinth on the floor of the nave. Many of this country’s kings are buried in a basilica which was rebuilt in the 12th century by Abbot Suger (“soo-JAIR”), who popularized Gothic architecture in this country. For 10 points, name this country home to the Abbey of St. Denis (“san-duh-NEE”) and Chartres (“shart”) Cathedral.
tossups.answer: France <WN, Other Arts - Architecture>

tossups.question: The protagonist of this story notes that children have gnawed on the bed, and comments that the room looks “as if a boys’ school had used it.” This story was inspired by the author’s struggles with neurasthenia, for which the author sought treatment from a doctor who developed the “West cure.” This story’s protagonist believes what her brother and husband say because they are (*) doctors. A pattern described as a “debased Romanesque” appears on the title object of this story. At the end of this story, the narrator tells her husband that she’s “got out at last,” appearing to have assumed the personality of the woman hidden in the design of the title object. For 10 points, name this story named for a psychosis-inducing room decoration, written by Charlotte Perkins Gilman.
tossups.answer: “The Yellow Wallpaper” <RR, Short Fiction>

tossups.question: A receptor partially named for this compound is activated by a peptide found in Gila monster venom. A peptide that is “like” this compound is an example of an incretin, whose production is blocked by DPP-4 inhibitors like Januvia. This compound upregulates a pathway that uses enzymes like HMG-CoA lyase to synthesize ketone bodies. This hormone stimulates a pathway whose rate-limiting step uses a (*) phosphorylase enzyme to break a terminal alpha 1 to 4 linkage. This hormone promotes the breakdown of triglycerides and glycogen, acting as the body’s main catabolic hormone. The alpha cells of the pancreas produce this hormone. For 10 points, name this hormone that raises the concentration of glucose in the bloodstream, which acts in opposition to insulin.
tossups.answer: glucagon <BB, Biology>

tossups.question: This country’s African-descended population was devastated by an 1871 yellow fever outbreak in its capital. One leader of this country carried out the Conquest of the Desert, which killed or displaced much of the indigenous population in its south. This country’s leading conservative newspaper, La Nación, was founded by its president Bartolomé Mitre. While exiled, this country’s future president Domingo Sarmiento wrote the book Facundo as an attack on the caudillo leader (*) Juan Manuel de Rosas. A revolutionary general from this country won the Battle of Chacabuco as part of his campaign for Chilean independence after completing the Crossing of the Andes. For 10 points, name this home country of José de San Martín whose presidents led from Buenos Aires.
tossups.answer: Argentina [or Argentine Republic; or República Argentina] <TR, World History>

tossups.question: A fragment of a work by this artist that depicts Pope Boniface VIII “proclaiming the Jubilee” is housed in San Giovanni in Laterano. This artist painted an Annunciation section of a larger work in which Mary and Gabriel are curiously on opposite ends of an arch. One of this man’s frescos included a narrow series of black-and-white Virtues and Vices. This Renaissance painter designed the Florence Cathedral’s bell-tower. He depicted people with torches and clubs in a panel that shows Jesus in profile in the (*) Kiss of Judas. This man painted part of a fresco with a blue background where the main characters face away from the viewer and ten angels cry out in pain above, his Lamentation. For 10 points, name this late Gothic artist whom Enrico Scrovegni (“scro-VAIN-yee”) commissioned to paint frescos for the Arena Chapel.
tossups.answer: Giotto di Bondone <AWD, Painting>

tossups.question: The Royal Philharmonic Orchestra accompanied recordings of this singer on the 2017 album A Brand New Me. In a song popularized by this singer, King Curtis plays a saxophone solo in F-sharp minor, despite the rest of the song being in C major. When Luciano Pavarotti was too ill to perform at the 1998 Grammy Awards, this singer performed “Nessun dorma” in his place. This artist’s backup vocalists sing (*) “Sock it to me” in her interpretation of an Otis Redding song. This artist, who honored Carole King at the Kennedy Center Honors by performing “(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman,” wore a gray jacket while singing “My Country, ’Tis of Thee” at the inauguration of Barack Obama. For 10 points, what singer of “Respect” was known as the “Queen of Soul” and passed away in August 2018?
tossups.answer: Aretha Franklin <KH, Other Academic>

tossups.question: A new military strategy in this country was shaped by a study written by Fred Kagan, General Jack Keane, and Ken Pollack. Attacks in this country often originated from the “Belts” around its capital city. After the conquest of this country, Paul Bremer was appointed head of the Coalition Provisional Authority. Two major battles were fought to take the city of (*) Fallujah in this country’s deadly Sunni Triangle. During a conflict here, the American president gave a speech on the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln proclaiming “Mission Accomplished.” A controversial “Surge” strategy was led in this country by General David Petraeus. American forces tortured prisoners in this country at Abu Ghraib. For 10 points, name this country once led by Saddam Hussein.
tossups.answer: Iraq <JZ, American History>

tossups.question: This character proclaims that tarantulas are the best “world-maligners” and “heretic-burners” in an extended discussion of a tarantula nest. This character analogizes one’s neighbors to “poisonous flies in the market-place” in a speech attacking society that he gives at the town of the Motley Cow. He has a dream in which he sees a devil with scornful laughter after a child shows him a mirror. This character, who spends ten years studying alone in the mountains, proclaims the idea of “eternal (*) recurrence” as a “joyful truth.” After speaking to an old man, this character expresses his author’s idea that “God is dead!” For 10 points, name this character who “speaks” in a philosophical novel by Friedrich Nietzsche, and who is named for a Persian prophet.
tossups.answer: Zarathustra [accept Also Sprach Zarathustra or Thus Spake Zarathustra; do not accept or prompt on “Zoroaster”] <IJ, Philosophy>

tossups.question: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe’s love for Friederike Brion inspired a poem about one of these objects on a heath. A poem named after one of these objects includes a lengthy coda in which personifications like Genius and Lady Reason discuss love and other topics, which comes after a more narrative-driven section that recounts a dream-vision in a walled garden. Christine de (*) Pizan’s Book of the City of Ladies was partly written as a feminist response to a 21,000-line poem named after one of these objects. Guillaume de Lorris and Jean de Meun wrote a medieval French allegorical poem entitled The Romance of [one of these flowers]. For 10 points, a Robert Burns poem compares the speaker’s love to what “red, red” object?
tossups.answer: roses <WN, Poetry>

tossups.question: This technique can be efficiently scaled up for industrial use with the simulated moving bed process. The resolution between two peaks in the output of this technique can be computed by the Purnell equation. Both distillation and this technique can be mathematically analyzed by splitting the apparatus into a series of “theoretical plates.” Highly charged resins are primarily used in water purification or in the (*) ion-exchange form of this technique. A pressurized mixture is fed into a tube lined with adsorbents in a “high-performance” type of this technique, which computes retention times based on how strongly they interact with materials like silica gel. Substances are separated using mobile and stationary phases in, for 10 points, what analytical technique which can be used to split marker ink into its constituent colors?
tossups.answer: chromatography [accept column chromatography or liquid chromatography] <KH, Chemistry> Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: A portable one of these buildings carried around during festivals is known as a mikoshi, and they contain a central honden (“HOHN-den”) that is generally closed to the public. For 10 points each:
answers: Shinto shrines [or jinja; accept English equivalents like Shinto temples]
Izumo Shrine [accept Izumo-taisha or Izumo Ōyashiro] <DM, Religion>
parts: Name these religious buildings that harbor kami. One of these buildings in Ise (“ee-say”) is torn down and rebuilt anew every 20 years.
Shinto shrine maidens often perform kagura, a ritual form of this general action. That tradition originates with Ame-No-Uzume, who did this action to help lure Amaterasu out of her cave.
According to Shinto tradition, all of the gods gather at this oldest Shinto shrine every October. It is dedicated to the kami Ōkuninushi.

bonuses.leadin: A poem describes this man as someone “whose name in arms through Europe rings / Filling each mouth with envy, or with praise.” For 10 points each:
answers: Thomas Fairfax, 3rd Lord Fairfax of Cameron
parts: Name this man, the addressee of a poem that describes Isabel Thwaites leaving a nunnery after a section on the architecture of “Appleton House,” which is the “Work of no Forrain Architect.”
The poet of “Upon Appleton House” wrote “An Horatian Ode” upon this man’s return. That poem about this man describes his inability to “cease / In the inglorious arts of peace.”
Those poems about Cromwell and Fairfax were written by this poet of “To His Coy Mistress.”

bonuses.leadin: This composer’s “Queen Mab Scherzo” was one of the first pieces to use crotales, or “antique cymbals.” For 10 points each:
answers: Romeo and Juliet [accept Roméo et Juliette]
Roman Carnival Overture [or Le carnaval romain ouverture caractéristique] <YFL, Music>
parts: Name this composer who wrote his first and most famous symphony in 1830 while he was obsessed with the actress Harriet Smithson.

Berlioz’s “Queen Mab Scherzo” was written as part of a “dramatic symphony” based on this play. Other pieces based on this Shakespeare play include an “Overture-Fantasy” by Tchaikovsky and a ballet by Prokofiev.
This colorfully orchestrated Berlioz piece features themes from his opera Benvenuto Cellini. Its exuberant opening in the strings is quickly cut off by a slow English horn solo in 3/4 time.

bonuses.leadin: This ruler reduced the influence of his court Mandarins by supporting foreign administrators such as the Greek Constantine Phaulkon. For 10 points each:
answers: Narai [or Ramathibodi III or Ramathibodi Si Sanphet]
parts: Name this Siamese king whose close ties to the French led to a 1688 rebellion against his rule, which resulted in Siam’s isolation from the West.
Narai ruled this kingdom, whose name is derived from the home city of Rama.
In 1686, an embassy from Narai travelled to the court of King Louis XIV at this palace in a suburb of Paris.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the mathematician Alston Scott Householder, for 10 points each.
answers: roots [prompt on solutions or zeroes or x-intercepts]
calculus of variations [or variational calculus; prompt on calculus]
reflections [accept reflection operations] <IJ, Other Science - Mathematics>
parts: Householder’s method finds these values of a function, which are inputs that make the function’s output zero.
Householder’s Ph.D. thesis dealt with this discipline, which seeks to find the extrema of functionals. In this discipline the Euler–Lagrange equations often reduce down to the Beltrami identity.

Householder developed a transformation that performs this operation through a plane or hyperplane. The Weyl (“vile”) group is an example of the group generated by the set of these operations in Euclidean space.

bonuses.leadin: A character interprets a thunderstorm in this village as an omen of his impending death. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this village where a man arrives and sits on a stone, which he is told is on ground sacred to the Furies.
This character arrives at Colonus in the second play of a trilogy by Sophocles. In the first play, he unwittingly kills his father Laius and sleeps with his mother Jocasta.

This daughter of Oedipus arrives on horseback at Colonus to inform Oedipus that his sons are fighting for control of Thebes. In a later play, she refuses to go with Antigone to bury their brother Polyneices.

bonuses.leadin: This discipline modifies many standard economic equations by adding an error term to account for random shocks. For 10 points each:
answers: regression [or linear regression; or auto-regression] <RR, Social Science - Economics>
parts: Name this discipline of economics that applies statistical modeling and computational techniques to observational economic data.
Many econometrics studies focus on the effect of this independent variable. ARIMA models are used to predict variables that depend on this independent variable.

ARIMA models are a combination of AR and MA models; AR models use a variable’s past performance as predictors in this statistical technique. This technique’s “linear” type may use a least squares approach to produce a line of best fit.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about ways of visualizing molecules, for 10 points each.
answers: electrostatic potential maps [accept electric potential maps] <BB, Chemistry>
parts: This American chemist’s “dot diagrams” visualize electrons in compounds.
In organic chemistry, the flow of electrons in chemical reactions is depicted using these shapes.

The shapes and distribution of charge in molecules can be visualized by making “maps” of this quantity. Those maps, which are similar to the electron density maps used in crystallography, use computational methods to make molecules into 3D globular surfaces, which are colored in based on the value for this quantity.

bonuses.leadin: The need for these figures, who are said to be connected to “goodness,” is dramatized with the “ship of state” metaphor, in which these figures are analogized to captains of very large boats. For 10 points each:
answers: philosopher kings [prompt on kings or philosophers]
parts: Name these idealized rulers discussed in the sixth book of an ancient Greek political treatise. Since they love wisdom, they should be able to make the best decisions for the public welfare.
Philosopher kings are praised by Socrates in this Platonic dialogue, which is named for a city representing a public form of government championed by Socrates.

Plato depicted this likely-fictitious Neopythagorean philosopher from Locri as having once held high office and having the qualities of a philosopher king. Like the unfinished Critias, the Platonic dialogue named for him presents the myth of Atlantis.

bonuses.leadin: This man organized Sweden into a system of counties that is still largely used today. For 10 points each:
answers: Axel Oxenstierna (“ook-sen-SHWANN-ah”), Count of Södermöre [accept either underlined answer]
Cardinal Richelieu [or Armand Jean du Plessis] <TR, European History>
parts: Name this chancellor of Sweden who worked with Gustavus Adolphus and served as regent for Queen Christina.
Christina became Queen Regnant after Gustavus Adolphus was killed at this battle of the Thirty Years’ War.
Oxenstierna allied Sweden with France, which was then led by this Cardinal who served as Louis XIII’s chief minister.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about interpretatio romana, a process by which writers like Tacitus reinterpreted non-Roman mythical traditions through a Roman lens, for 10 points each.
parts: Tacitus’s Germania identifies a goddess worshipped by the Suebi people as this Egyptian goddess, the subject of a small Roman cult. The Greek god Harpocrates is a version of this goddess’s son Horus.
Tacitus also mentions the Suebi goddess Nerthus, who is linguistically linked to this male Norse god, the father of Freyr and Freya. Skadi found herself attracted to this god’s beautiful feet.
Tacitus identifies Odin, the chief god of many Germanic pantheons, with this Roman god. Julius Caesar reported that he was popularly equated with the Celtic trade god Lugus in Gaul and Britain.

bonuses.leadin: This quantity depends on variables other than temperature for a Bingham plastic. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity whose “dynamic” form, symbolized mu, equals the ratio of shear stress to shear rate according to a law discovered by Isaac Newton.
Kinematic viscosity equals dynamic viscosity divided by this quantity. For water, this quantity equals approximately 1000 kilograms per meter cubed.
According to kinetic theory, the viscosity of a gas is linearly proportional to this value, denoted lambda. It represents the average distance travelled by a gas particle between collisions.

bonuses.leadin: Robert Louis Stevenson said that this author “had ceased to be human” after this man wrote “King Pest,” a story in which two sea men drown the title figure and his retinue using a barrel of ale. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author whose other barrel-centric stories include one in which a man’s hair turns from jet black to white as he survives a shipwreck by holding onto a barrel.
That Edgar Allan Poe story is set in Norway and is titled for a “Descent” into this kind of whirlpool.
Fortunato buries Montresor alive at the end of this Edgar Allan Poe story titled for a barrel of wine.

bonuses.leadin: Under William Colby, this organization compiled reports of its misdeeds known as the “Family Jewels,” most of which were released in 2007. For 10 points each:
answers: Frank Church [or Frank Forrester Church III; accept Church Committee]
colleges [or universities; accept any answer indicating college or university or campus or similar; prompt on less-specific answers such as “schools” or similar] <AH, American History>
parts: Name this American spy organization that journalist Seymour Hersh revealed to have been operating on domestic soil during the 1950s through 1970s, in violation of its charter.

In the 1970s, the CIA’s misdeeds were investigated by a committee led by and named for this Democratic senator from Idaho, which led to the passage of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, or FISA (“FYE-zuh”).

Investigations into the CIA were spurred when Ramparts magazine revealed that the agency had been funding the NSA, a coalition of governments based in these places. In the 1960s, Mario Savio led the Free Speech Movement from one of these places.

bonuses.leadin: This composer’s “Largo” is derived from his aria “Ombra mai fu,” which is sung by Xerxes to a tree he likes. For 10 points each:
answers: Giulio Cesare in Egitto [or Julius Caesar] <AWD, Other Arts - Opera>
parts: Name this composer of operas like Alcina, Rinaldo, and Serse.

Handel’s opera Rinaldo was the first Italian opera composed for this city, where Handel was the music director for the Royal Academy of Music. Handel’s Water Music was premiered on a river in this European capital.

A solo horn accompanies the title man’s aria “Va tacito” in this Handel opera based on ancient history. This opera’s female lead sings the mournful arias “Se pietà” (“say pyay-TAH”) and “Piangerò la sorte mia” (“pyahn-jay-ROH lah sor-tay MEE-ah”), and it includes the countertenor staples “Svegliatevi nel core” (“zvell-YAH-tay-vee nell KOH-ray”) and “Da tempeste.”

bonuses.leadin: The 1978 murder of Altab Ali by racist teenagers led to protests by immigrants originally from this country. For 10 points each:
answers: curry [accept specific varieties such as chicken tikka masala] <TR, Other History>
parts: Name this country, many of whose immigrants to the UK live in the Brick Lane neighborhood of London and originate from this country’s Sylhet region.
This politician gave the racist 1968 “Rivers of Blood” speech in opposition to mass immigration to the UK.
The many restaurants opened by Bengali immigrants have led to this common type of food being called Britain’s national dish.

bonuses.leadin: An artifact originating from an event involving this company was found on the shores of Réunion over a year after it occurred. For 10 points each:
answers: Malaysia Airlines Berhad [accept MH370 or Malaysia Airlines Flight 370]
lithium-ion batteries [prompt on batteries or lithium batteries]
parts: Name this company, the subject of a safety investigation report released in July 2018 that led to the resignation of Azharuddin Abdul Rahman and detailed the mystery behind the presumed deaths of 239 people.
When it went missing, Malaysia Airlines 370 was carrying 5,408 pounds of these items, which are usually banned in airport cabins.
Malaysian Airlines experienced another tragedy when MH17 was shot down by pro-Russian separatists over the Donetsk Oblast in this war-torn region of eastern Ukraine.

bonuses.leadin: A painting traditionally named after one of these people “in meditation” probably actually depicts a scene from the Book of Tobit. For 10 points each:
answers: Rembrandt (Harmenszoon) van Rijn [or Rembrandt van Rijn]
parts: Name this type of person, one of whom titles a painting in which he wears a jeweled belt and places his hand on top of a sculpture.
Philosopher in Meditation and Aristotle Contemplating a Bust of Homer are by this artist of The Night Watch.
In his book Rembrandt’s Eyes, this historian suggested that Aristotle Contemplating a Bust of Homer actually depicts a painter, not Aristotle. He presented the BBC documentary series Power of Art.

bonuses.leadin: Seizures in this part of the brain can cause déjà vu, amnesia, or dissociation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this lobe of the brain that is in contact with the frontal and parietal lobes. The medial portion of this lobe contains the hippocampus.
The temporal lobe contains an area named for this neurologist, which when damaged causes expressive aphasia. This neurologist also names a type of encephalopathy caused by thiamine deficiency.
Damage to the fusiform gyrus of the temporal lobe causes this condition, in which the sufferer is unable to recognize faces.

bonuses.leadin: The main female character of this novel is distressed to learn that a man named Daniel stole her husband’s rifle, and joined a group of fighters. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel where the aforementioned gun theft causes Maureen to break down and run towards an unidentified helicopter, which may be commanded by the black people who violently overthrew the government.
This author fictionalized a violent end to apartheid in July’s People. Her other works include one depicting the Soweto Riots, Burger’s Daughter.

To reach the village of July’s people, Maureen and Bamford ride for three days in this yellow vehicle, which Bamford originally purchased for a hunting trip. Give the six-letter name by which this vehicle is frequently referred in the novel.
